article.headline: Apple investors: Watch out for the winnersâ curse
article.body: Quick: What was the most valuable company in the world 10 years ago? If you guessed Apple AAPL, +1.74% Â â the most valuable today, with a market capitalization above $2 trillionâyouâd be wrong. In 2010, occupying the No. 1 spot was oil giant ExxonMobil XOM, -1.47%. Returns since then? Zero. The stock has dropped from $61 to about $41, and even with dividends youâve barely broken even â and thatâs before counting taxes and trading costs, let alone inflation. During the same period a standard, low-cost U.S. stock-market index fund has quadrupled your money. Thatâs true for the SPDR 500 Trust SPY, +0.89%, which follows the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% Â large-company index; the Vanguard Total Stock Market Index fund VTI, +0.84%, which follows that companyâs index of large, midsize and small companies; and many others. OK â what was the most valuable company in the world five years before that, in 2005? If you thought it was still Exxon, youâd be 0 for 2. Actually in early 2005 it was General Electric Co. GE, +2.85%. Â Returns since then: minus 70%. Yes, indeed. Even including reinvested dividends (and ignoring taxes, trading costs and inflation â we should all be so lucky). How about a few years before that? The biggest company on the stock market was Microsoft MSFT, +2.48%, and in 2001 it was briefly the megabank Citigroup C, +0.47%. Microsoft has been a terrific investment over that period â but only if you hung on for more than a decade. As for Citigroup: If you bought the stock in 2001, when it was the stock marketâs most valuable company, today youâd have lost 85% of your money. Yes, really. (And, once again, thatâs before deducting the costs you pay in the real world.) Go back to the 1980s and it would appear the stock market really anticipated the technology boom, because the worldâs most valuable company was a computer maker. Alas, it was IBM IBM, -2.81%. Love those mainframes! Oh, it made typewriters, too. OK, so this might look like a game. No doubt Appleâs legion of stockholders and other fans will argue that the company is no IBM, or GE, or Exxon, or Citigroup, so the analogy wonât apply. And all analogies break down eventually, so of course thatâs true. But there is serious research that shows not only that putting your money on the worldâs most valuable company has tended to be a poor long-term investment but that betting on the most valuable company in each sector has been, too. From around 1950 to 2010, âthe leader in any sector underperforms the average stock (equally weighted) in its own sector by nearly 4% in the next year â¦ and the next year â¦ and the next year. â¦ Put another way, with compounding, the top stock in the 12 U.S. market sectors declined 28% in value in 10 years, relative to the average stock in its respective sector, over the past 59 years.â Yikes. Does this mean Apple is going to be a terrible investment over the next decade? No, of course not. As the late Casey Stengel advised: Never make predictions, especially about the future. But. If Apple makes up a big chunk of your 401(k), IRA or other retirement account, do the math. Sorry. Apple investors have become used to the most staggering stock-market returns. Theyâve averaged 28% a year for 20 years. And so far the stock has earned them more than 70% â yes, really â since the start of this year. But in recent years, something has been happening that many investors may not fully appreciate. Appleâs stock has been rising far faster than its per-share earnings. So in five years the stock has gone from $100 to $500. But during the same period the per-share earnings have risen only from $9 to $13. At 33 times forecast earnings for the next 12 months, Apple is now more expensive in relation to fundamentals than at any time since 2007âwhen the iPhone was new, and the company was one-twentieth of its current size, with gigantic room to grow. If you are expecting Apple to earn you 28% a year ahead, youâre betting that in five yearsâ time the company will be not Americaâs first $2 trillion company, but the worldâs first $7 trillion company. Since 2015 Apple has gone from 11 times forecast earnings to 33 times. By 2025 are we expecting it to rise to 99 times? Just asking.
